page.title: 02LANDSCAPE OF DOWNS,EDINGTON.
page.content: The underlying rock south of the 6OOft contour line in this block consists of Middle and Upper Cretaceous chalk, the northern edge of Salisbury Plain. The narrow band of Lower chalk lies between 6OO and 4OOfeet where the scarp drops steeply to the Greensand. Example of Sandy Lane leading from the road going N.E. to Edington up to Piquet Hill. Gardens, allotments and orchards abut the road on the fertile soil above the sand. Luccombe Springs are dammed to form a mill pond. Constant flowing springs rise just below the junction of Chalk and Greensand, hence the growth of the settlements of Bratton and Edington from Saxon times.
